awd_titl_txt: Dynamical Tides in White Dwarf Binaries: Theory and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The end stage of a star like the Sun is a compact star called a white dwarf (WD). A white dwarf no longer produces energy by nuclear fusion, but will glow from residual heat for billions of years. A research team at Cornell University will study WDs that are in a binary system with another astrophysical object. These binary systems can lead to the formation of exotic objects (such as Type Ia supernovae or tidal disruption events), and they are important sources of low-frequency (mHz) gravitational waves (GWs) to be detected by the future Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA). This program will seek to understand the physics of tidal dissipation in the WD, the effect of tidal dissipation on the WD structure and evolution, and how tides affect the GW emission and detection. Visualizations of the results (such as gravity wave breaking and its connection to ocean waves and surfing) will be published on the web for educational purposes. This program will provide support for graduate students, who will receive training in many of the multidisciplinary areas, and in scientific computing. The lead investigator will continue to engage talented undergraduate students in research. 

The research team will carry out numerical simulations of tidal dissipation via nonlinear internal gravity wave breaking in binary WDs (with the goal of determining the tidal heating profile in the WD), study WD thermal evolution prior to merger, and quantify how tidal effects influence the optical emission and mHz GW signals. The team will also study the long-term evolution of highly eccentric WD-MBH binaries prior to tidal disruption of the WD. They will examine the chaotic growth of WD oscillation modes (“chaotic tides”) due to repeated pericenter passages around the MBH, taking account of the effect of gravitational radiation and WD rotation. The researchers will explore the linear and nonlinear dampings of these modes and study their effects on the WD evolution and mHz GW emission from the WD-MBH binaries. Compact WD binaries are an important source of GW radiation for LISA. The detection of GWs from WD binaries by LISA relies on matched filtering, where a library of template waveforms is matched against instrument data. As such, the accuracy and completeness of the template library is of utmost importance. The scientists will use their tidal binary WD evolution model to compute gravitational waveforms for use in the LISA detection pipeline. This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
e have carried out a series of theoretical/computational studies on

the astrophysics of white dwarf (WD) binaries and related systems

(such as WD-planet systems and their progenitor systems involving red

giants). Our research privides new understanding of various key physical processes

related to WD binaries and makes predictions to confront with

observations. A major focus of our research was to

understand the physics of tidal dissipation in the WD (including the

effect of rotation), the effect of tidal dissipation on the WD

structure and evolution (e.g. prior to binary mergers or WD disruption),

and how tides affect the GW emission/detection.  We have carried out

numerical simulations of tidal dissipation via nonlinear internal

gravity wave breaking in binary WDs (with the goal of determining the

tidal heating profile in the WD), studied WD thermal evolution prior to

merger, and quantify how tidal effects influence the optical emission

and mHz GW signals. We have also clarified the long-term evolution of

highly eccentric WD-BH binaries prior to tidal disruption of the

WD. The result showed that the chaotic growth of WD oscillation modes

(``chaotic tides'') due to repeated pericenter passages around the

MBH can play an important role in the evolution of these systems.

Overall, our research enhances the understanding of the key

physical processes in a variety of WD binary systems, particularly the

roles of tidal dissipation, and helps interpret

ongoing and future observations of various astrophysical sources in

both EM and gravitational wave windows.

 

Our research involves astrophysics, fluid mechanics and nonlinear

dynamics, and thus is of interest to a broad scientific community.

The research results have been published in refereed journals and

presented in appropriate scientific meetings.  The main funding for

this proposal have been used to provide GRA support for graduate

students, who have received training in many of the multidisciplinary

areas, and in scientific computing. Several postdocs have also been mentored to

work in these areas. The PI has integrated the latest research results

into graduate and undergraduate courses and in lectures targeting the

general public and middle-school students. The PI has

engages talented undergraduate students in the research.
